definition: antifragility is achieved by designing the system to benefit from disruptions
antifragility has been conceptually defined in terms of convex responses and asymmetric gains under stress.
antifragility ¦ is focused specifically on growth. it posits that a system can strengthen and grow through exposure to volatility and shocks, analogous to muscle growth through exercise.
while antifragility includes the aspect of robustness, which entails recovering from shocks, it goes further by striving to achieve an even higher level of performance subsequent to such shocks.
antifragility refers to when a system benefits from the variability of its environment, and fragility refers to when it suffers.
antifragility, instead, represents the capability of a system to absorb shocks and get better.
antifragility when systems absorb shocks and get better afterward. (taleb, 2012; hespanhol, 2017)
while a robust or resilient system resists failure and remains the same or recovers from failure, an antifragile system benefits from shocks, getting better. (lichtman et al., 2016; hespanhol, 2017)
antifragility ¦ demonstrates itself as the ability of a system to become stronger (up to an unknown point) after experiencing a stressor.

antifragility ¦ did not exist as a notion before nicholas taleb introduced it in 2012 as an antonym to fragility and demonstrates itself as the ability of a system to become stronger (up to an unknown point) after experiencing a stressor.
a system is antifragile if its performance improves as the result of exposure to stressors, shocks, or disruptions.
antifragility refers to when [a system] benefits from this variability. (taleb, 2012; taleb & douady, 2013)
̃antifragilitytm essentially describes systems that actually benefit from disorder, rather than suffer.
antifragility refers to a systemtms ability to benefit from disruptions and volatilitymanaging disturbances not only by enduring stress but by learning, adapting, and profiting from it.
antifragility characterizes systems that benefit from volatility and chaos, demonstrating enhanced performance when exposed to significant and seemingly unlikely variations in parameters.
antifragility refers to a systemtms capacity to increase performance when exposed to increasing uncertainty, representing a continuous or bounded function in which gains rise with volatility.

a system is antifragile when it benefits from noise or disorder. thus, noise acts as a constructive element that allows the system to perform a function successfully. therefore, one expects to encounter antifragility in a complex dynamical system that is nonlinear, has many degrees of freedom and is out of equilibrium.

a system is antifragile when it gains from disturbances (taleb, 2012). the average performance of an antifragile system increases as perturbations trigger selection and removal of underperforming system features, while the strongest features survive.

antifragility is the feature of a system that increases in resilience or robustness as a result of the harmful effects of stressful actions: malfunctions, shocks, errors, noise, mistakes, disturbances, attacks, faults, or failures. in other words, some systems (natural or artificial) can improve their performance and become better when subjected to various forms of stress.

antifragility refers to the design of information systems that leverage uncertainty for gains, shifting design philosophy from preserving function to expanding functionality and performance across a range of uncertain conditions.

antifragility refers to systems that gain from volatility and disorder and show an improvement in performance when subjected to large and seemingly implausible changes in parameters. antifragility encompasses robustness as it means the ability to recover after a shock, however, with the addition to achieve an even higher performance level afterwards.

antifragility and fragility are degrees on a spectrum, and we can almost always detect antifragility (and fragility) using a simple test of asymmetry: anything that has more upside than downside (convex) from random events (or certain shocks) is antifragile. anything that acts reversely is fragile. (russo & ciancarini, 2017)
antifragility refers to systems which gain from volatility and disorder and show an improvement in performance when subjected to large and seemingly implausible changes in parameters.
antifragility can be defined as the ability of a system to improve its functionality in the presence of external perturbations.

antifragility is a property of systems that increase in capability as a result of stressors, shocks, volatility, noise, mistakes, faults, attacks, or failures. according to n.n. taleb (2013): ̃antifragility is beyond resilience or robustness. the resilient resists shocks and stays the same; the antifragile gets better.tm

antifragility is defined as a convex response to a source of harm and so can lead to a positive response to an increase in volatility, as opposed to fragility which suffers from the variability of its environment beyond a certain pre-set threshold.

there may exist vulnerabilities and there may be exposure, but steps will be taken to mitigate weaknesses. upon experiencing adversities, a host of measures will be taken to strengthen the system. one will learn from the incident, and improve on the system in as many ways as are practical.
supply chain antifragility has emerged as a way of not only managing disruptions but also leveraging them as opportunities for growth.
antifragile supply chains not only withstand volatility and shocks but also thrive and improve from such disturbances.
the concept of antifragility, introduced by taleb (2012), offers a strategic alternative by proposing that businesses can improve and expand when exposed to volatility.
an antifragile supply chain is one that derives gainsboth financial and non-financialfrom disruption.

antifragility emphasizes the capacity of business ecosystems to become more resilient in the face of vuca events, fostering adaptability, flexibility, and learning from disruptions within the supply chain.
supply chains that are resilient and antifragilecapable of surviving and thriving amid disruptions.

while a resilient supply chain aims at absorbing shocks, an antifragile supply chain sees these shocks as an opportunity to get stronger and better. an antifragile supply chain does not only respond to disruption but also thrives in it (taleb, 2012).

unlike robust or resilient supply chains, the antifragile supply chain ̃lovestm disorder and thrives in the world of randomness. in other words, robust and resilient supply chains are placed on a continuum from the fragile to antifragile supply chain.
this emerging concept aims to endure extreme events ¦ fostering learning, adaptation, and the exploitation of opportunities to enhance performance and foster growth.

while resiliency and robustness emphasize maintaining the status quo and only show flexibility in reaction to disturbances without actively seeking improvement, antifragility emphasizes improvement and learning from disruptions.
unlike robustness and resilience, which aim to withstand or return to a pre-shock state, antifragility suggests a capacity for evolutionary improvement in the face of adversity.
antifragility implies the tendency of an organization to improve its own competitive position in the face of a crisis, while resilience does not.

talebtms theory of antifragility describes a systemtms ability to withstand stress and change caused by capital, large-scale, and massive events, that are largely unpredictable; nonetheless, at the core of antifragility is the idea of thriving and improving in response to various kinds of shocks.
antifragile organizations are better prepared to respond to crises and emerge more robust¦ transforming [risks] into opportunities.

antifragility, a critical characteristic of systems that thrive under stress, shocks, errors, and failures, will play a pivotal role in ensuring adaptability and robustness in the face of global challenges, such as climate change and biodiversity issues.
antifragility goes beyond resilience by proposing that systems have the potential to not just survive but also flourish and gain advantages from these very disruptions.

antifragility is a new concept that designers of scnd increase the capability of facilities to cope with types of disruptions like stressors, fluctuations, volatility, and shocks. 2. the resilient policy is flexible against shocks and back to normal mode, but the antifragility concept utilizes disruptions and moves to improvement.

antifragility is positioned as a progression from robustness and resilience, with a positive end-point. where robustness ends in failure, and resilience restores the status quo (plus/minus some possible lasting impacts on performance), antifragility theoretically would result in permanent positive improvement and enhanced performance.

organizations can experience three distinct outcomes after facing adversity: (1) performance degradation followed by recovery (i.e., resilience), (2) insensitivity to uncertainty (i.e., robustness), and (3) upside gain (i.e., antifragility).
the term antifragility defines the property or capacity of systems (beyond robustness and resilience) to potentially benefit or even thrive when exposed to these change or disorder effects.

the implications of antifragility go beyond resilience or robustness. a resilient system resists stress and remains the same; while an antifragile system improves. (jaaron & backhouse, 2014; citing taleb, 2012)

to maintain organisational growth in a turbulent environment, organisations must build highly effective learning systems to innovate and develop from threats and stressors. this has been termed by taleb (2012s) as ̃antifragility.tm the capacity to learn from stressors in order to flourish.
when programs or units are antifragile, they stand to gain from inevitable volatility rather than be harmed by it.
antifragility is principally more than resilience or robustness.
the resilient resists black swans and remains the same but the antifragile knowledge gets better and better.
an antifragile firm benefits from disorder.
taleb¦ suggested establishing a robust yet transformative and emergent environment, which equips the system with the knowledge and capacity to deal with and capitalize on uncertainty.
the ability to deal with uncertainty completely and internally consistently is an essential characteristic of antifragility.
the antifragility concept utilizes disruptions and moves to improvement.
the concept of gaining from uncertainty referred to as antifragility.
antifragility¦ regenerates itself continuously by using, rather than suffering from, random events, unpredictable shocks, and volatility.

the concept of antifragile was created by nicholas nasim taleb in 2012. it is a neologism that taleb uses to define the opposite to ̃fragiletm¦ the opposite is what not only does not deteriorate, break down and/or collapse but also improves.
taleb called it antifragile and introduced the concept of antifragility as a property beyond robustness and resilience. (russo & ciancarini, 2017)

according to taleb (2012), the idea behind antifragility is to survive (even thrive) in the age of complexity and volatility when dealing with unknown randomness and disruptions. (taleb, 2012; russo & ciancarini, 2017; hespanhol, 2017)
